newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries open up, official rates seen steady.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries open up, official rates seen steady.

text.p: By Ellen Freilich
U.S. government securities prices opened higher Wednesday as investors anticipated that a meeting of Federal Reserve policymakers would end with a decision to hold interest rates steady.

The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Fed, began a two-day meeting Tuesday that is widely expected to end with an announcement this afternoon that rates will be left unchanged.
Recent economic data have portrayed a second quarter characterized by subdued inflation and economic growth that slowed from a very brisk first quarter.

In the most recent report, the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) yesterday reported its index for June provided more evidence that healthy economic growth was not fanning worrisome inflation.
Bond prices rose and yields fell on Tuesday as a result of the NAPM report, participants said. Wednesday's early strength was followthrough buying on those gains, they said.
In early trade, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was up 4/32 to 98-20/32, yielding 6.73 percent.
Two-year notes opened at 99-31/32, up 1/32 to yield 6.02 percent.
"The market has a bid to it that it held on to overnight," said Kim Rupert, senior economist at Standard and Poors MMS. "That helped give a bid to European bonds as well."
Rupert said the market "is pretty sanguine" about the FOMC meeting.
"So (these early gains are) just a continuation of yesterday's gains," she said.
The only piece of government economic news the market will get today is May factory orders. Economists polled by Reuters forecast a 0.2 percent decline, after a 1.2 percent increase in April.
"Factory orders shouldn't have much impact," said Rupert.
Participants said position-squaring before the government releases the June monthly payroll report on Thursday could be the main feature of trading this afternoon.
Economists polled by Reuters forecast, on average, that payrolls expanded by 222,000 jobs in June and the unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.8 percent.
Average hourly earnings are expected to be up 0.4 percent after a 0.3 percent rise in May.
"The market expects something on the healthy side for payrolls," said Rupert, citing estimates for gains of up to 250,000.

"There's been talk of a risk of a higher number," she added, "so even though we might see a kneejerk down reaction (by the market) on a number like 250,000, by the end of the day that could be absorbed -- as long as the hourly earnings number and the unemployment rate aren't too bad."
In early dealings, the 10-year note was up 3/32 at 101-13/32, with a yield of 6.43 percent. The five-year note was up 2/32 at 99-24/32, yielding 6.31 percent.
Three-month bills were unchanged at 5.10 percent and six-month bills were unchanged at 5.12 percent. Year bill rates were down one basis point to 5.33 percent.
((--North American Treasury Desk, 212-859-1679))
